criteria: Evaluation of Effects on Use and Abuse
descriptions: Demonstrates no understanding of marketing techniques used to promote alcohol, tobacco, and other drugs.
Shows a limited understanding of one or two marketing techniques.
Identifies several marketing techniques but struggles to explain them clearly.
Clearly explains several marketing techniques and how they are used.
Provides a comprehensive explanation of various marketing techniques, including persuasive language and imagery.
Offers a nuanced understanding of sophisticated marketing strategies, including targeted advertising and psychological manipulation.
Fails to analyze the influence of marketing and advertising on substance use.
Offers a basic analysis with limited supporting evidence.
Analyzes the influence with some evidence, but connections are superficial.
Provides a solid analysis of the influence of marketing and advertising, supported by relevant evidence.
Presents a well-reasoned analysis that thoroughly explores the influence and impact of marketing on substance use.
Presents a insightful and critical analysis, demonstrating an advanced understanding of how marketing contributes to substance use and abuse.
Unable to evaluate the effects of marketing and advertising on alcohol, tobacco, and other drug use and abuse.
Attempts to evaluate the effects, but provides little supporting information.
Offers a limited evaluation of effects, mentioning a few potential consequences.
Evaluates the effects with specific examples and demonstrates an understanding of potential consequences.
Provides a comprehensive evaluation of the short-term and long-term effects of marketing on substance use and abuse.
Critically evaluates the effects, offering insights into the complexities of addiction and the role of marketing in perpetuating harmful behaviors.
